bioc:owner.description: The user's IAM user name with the suffix @bioconductor.

bioc:creator.title: User who created this resource, if created manually
bioc:creator.description: The user's IAM user name with the suffix @bioconductor.

bioc:application-id.title: Application Identifier
bioc:application-id.description: This tag identifies a specific application that is uniquely served by this resource

bioc:environment.title: The execution environment
bioc:environment.description: The execution context. For example, production, testing,  or development

bioc:availability.title: Availability Category
bioc:availability.description: Availability category indicates the relative importance of having the system on line and available for its users

bioc:retain-until.title: Expiration date
bioc:retain-until.description: Do not deaccession, shutdown or deprecate the resource before this date.

bioc:recovery-objective:point.title: RPO. Recovery point objective,
bioc:recovery-objective:point.description: The maximum data loss that this systemp can tolerate without significant impact, measured as a time interval. For example if the system fails catastropyically at 9:00, a RPO of 30 minutes (P30M) implies that in the worst-case scenario, the system must be able to recover all the system data at up through 8:30

bioc:recovery-objective:time.title: RTO. Recovery time objective
bioc:recovery-objective:time.description: The maximum down-time duration that this systems or processes that depend on this resource can tolerate without significant impact. For example, an RTO of 1 hour (P1H) means that after a catastrophic failure at 11:20, the system must be back in operation no later than 12:20.

bioc:notes.description: Free-form text attached to the resource.
